title: Practice Challenge
description: Apply what you've learned in this interactive coding challenge.
instructions:
Create a simple product catalog using records!

1. Create a record 'Product' with: string Name, decimal Price, string Category
2. Create 3 products: 'Laptop' ($999.99, 'Electronics'), 'Coffee' ($12.99, 'Food'), 'Book' ($24.99, 'Books')
3. Display all products using their automatic ToString()
4. Create a discounted version of Laptop with price $899.99 using 'with'
5. Compare two identical products to show value equality

hints.text: Use 'public record Product(string Name, decimal Price, string Category);' for the one-line definition. Use 'm' suffix for decimal literals (999.99m).
For 'with' expressions, syntax is: var newRecord = oldRecord with { Property = newValue };. Original remains unchanged!
Records use value equality by default. Two records with identical property values are equal (==), unlike regular classes.

commonMistakes.mistake: Trying to modify record properties directly
commonMistakes.consequence: Record properties are init-only by default. Use 'with' expressions to create modified copies instead of trying to change properties.
commonMistakes.correction: Use: var updated = original with { Property = newValue };

commonMistakes.consequence: Decimal literals need the 'm' suffix (999.99m). Without it, C# treats them as double and causes type mismatch errors.
commonMistakes.correction: Always use 'm' suffix for decimal values: 12.99m, 999.99m

commonMistakes.consequence: Records compare by VALUE, not reference. Two separate record objects with same data are equal (==).
commonMistakes.correction: Understand that records are designed for value semantics - same data means equal.
